_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This summary reflects the conditions at the time of the June 21st RMP re-submittal.

TSE Industries, Inc., the worlds foremost maker of millable urethane rubber was started almost fifty years ago and has never had an accident affecting offsite health or the environment. With our current accidental release prevention program and emergency response policy we anticipate another fifty safe years for TSE and our commercial and industrial neighbors.

The accidental release prevention plan is successful because of the following characteristics.
? All of the affected processes are designed or directed by qualified chemical or process engineers.
? The operation is accomplished within the framework of an ISO 9001 organization (independently registered and randomly audited for compliance by Underwriters Laboratories (UL)) where each task is completed using a checklist or SOP (standard operation procedure). Deviations to procedure require evaluation and approval by competent engineers.
? The storage tanks are of double wall, stainless steel construction and are installed within a diked area that can contain the entire contents of the tank. Additionally, the tanks are inside the building.
? The entire facility is covered by an automatic fire protection system.
? When removed from the tanks for use, the material is drawn out using vacuum, not pressure. This eliminates the possibility of tank failure from over-pressurization.
? The plant uses security personnel during non-occupied hours to prevent unauthorized entry or vandalism.

TSE's emergency response policy is maintained and practiced periodically. We have a good working relationship with the Pinellas Park Fire Department that has received material safety data sheets for the chemicals at TSE. They have two stationhouses within five minutes of the plant that are equipped and trained to respond to hazardous materials incidents. They receive a copy of our contingency plan yearly and whenever it is revised. The plan contains a si

te map of the facility. 

The Pinellas County Sheriff, Pinellas Park Police and Local Emergency Planning Committee receive copies of the contingency plan yearly and whenever it is revised.

TSE has a contract with SWS Environmental First Response, Inc. a major emergency response provider. In the event of an emergency TSE may also call on the resources of the Bayer Corporation, the manufacturer of the material, if the need should arise.

The facility is located in the northern most part of Pinellas Park, Florida in an industrial park. We are situated on approximately three acres of land with various industrial and commercial businesses to the North and East and the back of a shopping center to the South and West. The property is separated from adjoining land and buildings on the East, South and West by trees, a creek, a stormwater retention pond and chain link fence. The area has numerous trees of various types and sizes.

TSE is a producer of millable urethane (Millathane) rubber which is used to produce many types of products from ATM machine money dispensing belts to the soles of high-tech running shoes made by some of the worlds most recognizable names in sports apparel. We also produce hot-melt and foam urethane based adhesives that are essential for the fabrication of many items of everyday use.

The process for the production of Millathane is essentially the precise combination of two major constituents, the toluene diisocyanate and a "polyol" (a group of chemicals similar to castor oil) as well as small amounts of various modifiers in a machine that dispenses it into five-gallon pails. It then cures to form a material that looks very much like the urethane that in-line roller skate wheels are made of.

The other process that uses toluene diisocyanate makes a product that TSE calls "T9". This product is used as a curing agent for very hard urethanes used on such things as printing rollers and as an adhesion promoter when adhering rubber to fabric, as in variou

s gasket and diaphragm materials. This product is made by mixing the toluene diisocyanate in a vessel with a catalyst to produce a dimer (two molecules stuck together) of the toluene diisocyanate. The dimer is a solid material that is then extracted from the carrier solution and dried.

Each of these processes has a 6,000-gallon storage tank for the toluene diisocyanate used in the product. Each tank is within a separate concrete containment area capable of collecting and containing the contents of the entire tank.

The worst case scenario presented for each of the two processes is the same. The storage tanks containing the toluene diisocyanate (TDI) are the same size, 6000 gallons, and each is in a diked enclosure within the main building. Both contain mixed isomers of TDI, although not the same proportion.The two containment areas have a slightly different surface area (about 11 square feet difference), but the calculated toxic end points are essentially the same, 44.41 feet and 45.23 feet. 

The evaporation rate of water is approximately 720 times that of TDI. If an ounce of water took one hour to evaporate, it would take 30 days for the same amount of TDI. Because the tanks are corrosion resistant double walled stainless steel and situated within a concrete enclosure it is difficult to imagine a scenario in which the contents of the entire tank could be released rapidly.

TSE has written training and supplemental computerized audio/visual material for generalized safety and accident prevention programs. Additionally, employees are trained within the department on their specific job function. TSE is an ISO 9001 company with Underwriters Laboratories. One of the requirements within the ISO quality standard is strict adherence to written operating procedures. These procedures are in place for the products produced from TDI. The value of this to safe operation is that deviation from the standard procedures is not permitted without through analysis and authorization

of the change. This system significantly reduces the opportunity for human error to cause unexpected consequences. In addition to these constraints, hot work, line breaking and lockout-tagout permits help assure that maintenance or contractors do not make careless mistakes.

TSE's emergency response plan requires evacuation of the building once an alarm has sounded. The emergency number "911" will be called. The first responder will be the PPFD that has both the equipment and trained personnel to respond to a hazardous materials incident. They have two stationhouses within five minutes of the facility. Clean up of materials will be handled by a professional emergency response company, SWS Environmental First Response, with which we have an existing agreement. SWS is also located in Pinellas Park. Our plan is reviewed at least once a year to assure currency. If significant changes are made to the operations the plan will be revised and sent to all of the external holders of the plan.
